article_title: Monday letters: Kevin McHale, high-speed rail, roaches
article_text: To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to HoustonChronicle.com.

article_metadata.description: Regarding "Doctors' group opposes drug ads" (Page D1, Friday) and "Blaming Affordable Care Act, UnitedHealth cuts profit outlook" (Page D3, Friday) I am encouraged by the two articles  that I hope will begin to make average Americans question our current health care laws without being spoon-fed from special-interest groups and politicians who take campaign funds from them.  A recent business column  pointed out there are no marketplace PPO plans offered in Houston because those companies can't make a profit, either ("The president's Affordable Care Act needs repair, not repeal," Page D1, Nov. 15).  [...] in the case of inelastic services where market prices don't change demand due to need - in the case of health insurance and certain prescription drugs - we need the government to act on our behalf.  Compare the cost of any drug paid in the U.S. to the same drug sold in other advanced countries and you will see how we are being taken advantage of by our lack of "buying power" with the pharmaceutical companies.  [...] should a commuter rail be done heading toward College Station - as has been talked about for years - and either a rail line or express bus service to Katy, it would connect two of the fastest-growing areas in the region to what could be a new hub.
article_metadata.author.name: Copyright 2015: Houston Chronicle
